title.narrative: IWMI 2018 - 2021: Wastewater reuse in the MENA region: Addressing the challenges
IWMI 2018 - 2021: Återanvändning av spillvatten i MENA-regionen.

description.narrative: A four year project implemented by IWMI in three countries 2018-2021 (Jordan, Lebanon and Egypt), with a purpose to enhance the sustainable use of water management and the reuse of wastewater, by which resilience against climate change is increased.

Ett fyraårigt projekt som genomförs av IWMI i tre länder 2018-2021 (Jordanien, Libanon och Egypten), i syfte att bidra till hållbar vattenhushållning och öka återanvändning av spillvatten samt därigenom förbättra moståndskraft gentemot klimatförändringar.

The proposed support to International Water Management Institute, IWMI, for their four year project "Wastewater Reuse in the MENA Region: Addressing the Challenges", will enable and strengthen capacity of stakeholders at regional, national and local levels of water resource management (users, providers, professionals/experts, decision-makers, policy makers and media). The project will work in selected sites in three countries, Lebanon, Egypt and Jordan, to facilitate on the ground capacity development for the safe reuse of wastewater through the formation of so called Learning Alliances. These alliances provide the opportunity to bridge the gap between scientists and experts on the one hand, and the stakeholders in wastewater management and reuse on the other. Learning alliances, in addition, work across levels to link local and national project nodes to regional learning an vice versa. The project therefore has a strong participatory design, where stakeholders come in for different purposes and at different levels. The outcomes of the project therefore range from:
(1) Project stakeholders' capacity for the sustainable and safe reuse of wastewater in the MENA region; (2) the preparation of national plans for the expansion of wastewater treatment and reuse in three countries; (3) the preparation of local wastewater treatment and reuse plans; and (4) the production of the MENA wastewater reuse sourcebook.
The sourcebook will bring together the selected reuse case studies, the catalogue of reuse models, the thematic advisory notes and relevant reference materials and resources. The sourcebook will be a key reference for wastewater professionals and other stakeholders in the MENA region responsible for the adoption, replication and sustainability of reuse initiatives after the end projects.
The Sida contribution will enable the project to work with the sustainability of water, and the safe resuse of wastewater in the MENA region, but will at the same time strengthen and aim to mainstream gender equality in water resource management, including wastewater reuse in general. The importance of this is recognized in the project design and work plan of the implementing partner (IWMI), through the involvement of men and women at all levels during project implementation, capacity development for partners and stakeholders. This design is supported with a budget for the costs of gender mainstreaming and will provide opportunity for continuous dialogue between Sida, project implementers and stakeholders.

description.narrative: 2019 represents the second reporting period of the MENA ReWater Project to Sida and covers the implementation period March – December 2019, after the inception period of March 2018 – March 2019. 2019 represents launching of sub-partners’ activities after finalizing agreements during the inception period. Following are couple of example results achieved in 2019: The MENA water reuse sourcebook is planned to have three volumes of 1) State of water reuse in MENA 2) Featured water reuse cases catalogue and 3) Thematic guidelines. The initial drafts were presented in the inception report. The proposed outline, authors and expected content of the three volumes were developed in 2019. IWMI has compiled more than 120 regional cases on water reuse for productive purposes including agricultural irrigation, landscape irrigation and more. This inventory of reuse cases is validated through consultation that was addressed to more than 150 stakeholders in the framework of the Regional Learning Alliance (RLA). The project’s National Steering Committees (NSCs) is a mechanism invested to provide coordinated and strategic guidance on further developments on water reuse policies and strategies at national level. NSC in Egypt prioritized four proposed sites to be the local wastewater reuse plans during the first NSC meeting on March 2019: Matrouh, Luxor, Kafr El Sheikh, and West Delta. After carrying out field visits, Luxor and Kafr El Sheikh were selected. In Jordan, Royal Scientific Society (RSS) in consultation with Jordan’s NSC, selected two settlements: the first is Shounneh Asshmaliah in Wadi Arab (Northern Jordan Valley) and its surrounding downstream agricultural land as an example of indirect reuse model, and the second one, is Wadi Assir treatment plant and its surrounding downstream agricultural land as an example of direct reuse model. The selection and pre-characterization of these two sites was validated during the second NSC held on November 2019. For Lebanon, the first NSC was held on May 2019 where two sites were selected, namely Joub Ablah and Zahle, for the development of local reuse plans. National Learning Alliances (NLAs) are composed of a broad range of stakeholders from the public, private sectors, policy makers, practitioners and researchers, that are engaged for consultation and validation of the baselines, policies and strategies developed by the project with the guidance of the NSC. In Egypt, the first NLA was held on May 2019 and aimed at gathering all stakeholders to start discussing the status of wastewater reuse in Egypt, and the institutional structure of the organizations responsible for water reuse. It concluded that the financial and economic situation, the question of social acceptance and the lack of coordination between institutions are among the main barriers to expand safe water reuse. These conclusions will be contributing to develop further the reuse national baseline assessment. In Jordan, the first NLA was held on July 2019 under the patronage of the Minister of Water and Irrigation with aim at sharing information, exchanging knowledge and generating innovating solutions for the most pressing problems associated with wastewater treatment and reuse in Jordan. A main conclusion was, that despite the well-structure system and long practice of wastewater treatment and reuse in Jordan, the responsibilities among ministries and relevant stakeholders are still overlapped. A second NLA meeting was held on December 2019 aimed to discuss the perception of farmers towards wastewater reuse in Northern Jordan Valley. The first NLA was held in Lebanon on October 2019 and paved the way of necessary conditions to implement reuse plans in Lebanon and to reflect on the needed data and its accessibility for the baseline assessment. The project is also facilitating a development of a revised waste water reuse standards in Lebanon in cooperation with the Lebanese Standards Institution (LIBNOR). In 2019, a committee has been formed to discuss with various experts the norms for wastewater reuse in agriculture based on ISO norms. A regional gender workshop was held on June 2019 in Cairo for staff and partners. The workshop aimed to introduce the implementing partners the importance of understand the meaning of gender and the concept of gender mainstreaming. The workshop also aimed to move further and mainstream gender in the implementing partners’ activities in their work plans. SIDA’s gender policy, the water reuse policies in the region and case studies from IWMI’s work in several countries were presented and discussed. More can be found on the project’s website http://rewater-mena.iwmi.org/
